text: hey guys it's Elise and welcome back to
my cupcake addiction today's episode is
all about surprises surprise eggs in
fact I'm going to show you guys how to
make a giant DIY kinder surprise egg
which is much larger than the standard
size Kinder Surprise eggs and today's
video is a collaboration with my friends
over at fluffy jet Productions if you
haven't checked out fluffy jet
Productions I will leave a link to them
down below
they do everything surprise so they do
surprise play-doh eggs they do surprise
kinder eggs they do toy unboxing there
is a ton of fun stuff on the fluffy jet
channel so make sure that you go and
check it out they'll also be cracking
open our surprise eggs at the end of
today's video so you guys can see what I
decided to fill mine with of course you
can fill them with whatever you like
let's get started I'm going to show you
how to make your own Kinder Surprise
eggs at home so it's up to you if you
want to personalize your kinder egg a
little bit using some colored candy
melts but today I've got some melted
white chocolate and some melted milk
chocolate so mine looks like a proper
kinder egg and for my shape today I'm
using an Easter egg chocolate mold so if
you don't have an easter egg mold
kicking around from one of your previous
Easter's they are always available on
eBay as a bit of an optional extra I've
given you guys some Kinder Surprise
printables and I've just printed mine
out on some sticky labels and kind of
cut them into a little bit of an egg
e-type shape I've got a spoon and a
knife I've also got my little surprise
package from fluffy Jett so you can't
quite see what's in there but if you go
and check out their video all will be
revealed
you'll also need some baking paper or
some wax paper and I'm going to present
mine today in some little clear plastic
bags but I found these really cute
little packets of Wilton cookie stack
presentation kits it has like a little
silver board and they have a nice long
clear plastic bag and a ribbon so
they're kind of all ready to go for your
Kinder Surprise presentation and
packaging I thought the ribbon was a
little thin so I've also got some nicer
fatter ribbon and just some plain clean
tissues let's get into it to make your
outer chocolate shell you just want to
take some of that melted milk chocolate
and fill your egg
about halfway so just pour it straight
in now you just want to tilt your egg
all the way around so that your
chocolate comes all the way up to the
sides of the egg you don't want any gaps
on the inside of that mold if you've got
one of those Easter egg molds that has
both halves in the same mold do both at
once just use a bigger bowl tip that egg
upside down drain off any excess
chocolate and you should have this
really nice smooth coating and then flip
it onto its flat side onto your baking
paper setting it on its flat side gives
you this really nice little lip which
makes it really easy to join together
but you don't want that to be too big so
I just used a sharp knife to kind of
just shave off any thicker parts of it
and I just set these on the bench not in
the fridge so the chocolates not brittle
so now it's time to fill your mold with
your white chocolate and you don't want
your white chocolate to be too hot so
melted and just let it sit for about 15
minutes once again take it all the way
up to the edges and then tip it out
so that's your nice smooth inner layer
of white chocolate and you want to place
that facedown onto your baking paper let
that sit on the bench for at 15 minutes
and then use your knife just to tidy up
those edges again and then pop it off in
the fridge for about 20 minutes before
you try to extract it it'll make the
chocolate shrink a little bit away from
the mold and make it much easier to pop
out you want to be careful here how much
you handle your Easter eggs so I've got
my clean dry tissues because any time I
touch them I'm gonna place fingerprints
onto them and we don't want that so I'm
lining my hand with a tissue so that I
can insert my little gift or my little
kinder surprise surprise so make sure
that you use your melted milk chocolate
to stick these together not the white
chocolate because you don't want to see
that white chocolate on the outside and
I just used a spoon but you can also use
a ziplock bag if you're not confident
you're going to be that neat just to
place a nice little line of the milk
chocolate and then carefully place your
second half of your egg on top grab
another tissue and use that to sort of
squeeze the two together and then if you
have any overlay or any excess just use
that sharp knife and a really sharp
knife works best here just to sort of
trim off the seals so that it's really
really nice and neat take one of your
little silver boards and just drizzle a
little spoonful of that melted milk
chocolate to the board that's going to
kind of glue our egg in place so it
doesn't roll around and it stands up
nicely and holding it with the tissue
play
your egg down on that nice little blob
or that little stand of melted milk
chocolate I will also mention here I am
using compound chocolate so I'm not
using a couverture chocolate or a real
chocolate I'm using a compound or a
cooking chocolate Nestle melts are great
for this slide your egg into your bag
twist it at the top and finish it off
with a great big ribbon tied in a nice
over-the-top bow and one of those
gorgeous little sticky Kinder Surprise
labels so obviously you guys can put
whatever you like into your surprise
eggs if you want to see what I decided
to put into mine make sure that you
click on the link below head on over to
fluffy jet productions and check out
their opening of my Kinder Surprise eggs
I will also add Oliver got to keep the
toys from inside these eggs and he is
most impressed with his prize as always
guys thanks very much for tuning in to
my cupcake addiction
